answers.answer: According to the ADA - fasting levels of 126 or higher indicate diabetes.  According to the ACE - it is a lower number.  Have a yearly physical and request a tolerance test - it's your money so spend it your way.Get a monitor and check your fasting (when you wake up) and your before meal readings and your 2 hour after meal readings.Go to the websites for ADA (American Diabetes Association) and the ACE and print out their numbers for acceptable blood sugar readings and then compare them to that.I am slender as well and have Type 2 Diabetes so - go figure- right?You can also go to the doc forum and post the same question and the "doctor" will address it....Hope all goes well....
Thanks so much for your response. I appreciate it .

question: Hi,My question is about when to become concerned about blood sugar readings. The last check-up I had last year showed fasting blood sugar was still normal with a score of 90.  99 was the upper limit of normal on the reference range. This was 10 points higher than it was two years ago.Is it too soon to request glucose tolerance testing?My mother is a type 2 diabetic, two of her sisters were as well and died of diabetic complications. One had an amputation as did a brother of my father who was diabetic.I also have Hashimoto's thyroid disease.I am physically active, exercise daily and am of slender weight but so is my mother and were my aunts.Also, when I urinate it smells like a donut shop, It's the only way I can think to describe it, sorry.I eat a lot of fruits, veggies and whole grain foods.So I guess my question is if I just sit and wait to see what happens as the fasting glucose rises, or are there tests that will indicate a problem earlier?
title: When To Test Further
